questions.question_text:
A company that has been breached multiple times is looking to protect cardholder data. The previous undetected attacks all mimicked normal administrative-type behavior. The company must deploy a host solution to meet the following requirements:
✑ Detect administrative actions
✑ Block unwanted MD5 hashes
✑ Provide alerts
✑ Stop exfiltration of cardholder data
Which of the following solutions would BEST meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

comments.content: IPS cannot block unwanted MD5 hashes. That's EDR's specialty. Actually, only EDR here is capable of doing that, in addition to providing alerts on various types of behavior, including detection of admin actions. Check out Carbon Black EDR.
Why would it be EDR and not HIPS? I'm not too familiar with EDR and I'm not seeing the big difference or advantage of one over the other.

discussion.content:
I think the answers should be B and D.
B. EDR can meet the following requirements:
 Detect administrative actions
 Block unwanted MD5 hashes
 Provide alerts
D. DLP can meet the following requirements:
 Provide alerts
 Stop exfiltration of cardholder data
I would take out EDR and replace it with DLP.

comments.content: so your answer is DLP & DLP?

questions.question_text:
An organization is in the process of integrating its operational technology and information technology areas. As part of the integration, some of the cultural aspects it would like to see include more efficient use of resources during change windows, better protection of critical infrastructure, and the ability to respond to incidents.
The following observations have been identified:
1. The ICS supplier has specified that any software installed will result in lack of support.
2. There is no documented trust boundary defined between the SCADA and corporate networks.
3. Operational technology staff have to manage the SCADA equipment via the engineering workstation.
4. There is a lack of understanding of what is within the SCADA network.
Which of the following capabilities would BEST improve the security position?

discussion.content: I think it is B. "There is a lack of understanding of what is within the SCADA network." A SIEM will provide visibility within the SCADA network.
I think it is C. HIPS is software. SIEM is software. NAC is software. The only choice that is entirely hardware-based (at least normally) is C.

In the All-in-One exam guide on page 200 under “critical infrastructure” is written:
Always protect the SCADA systems from other networks with a firewall.
B has higher chance

comments.content: also SIEM is much advanced than Log Monitoring. VPN does more than NAC.

discussion.content: I believe D is the answer. All the rest of the answers involve software having to be installed, D is the only answer that doesn't require any software to be installed on the machine.

comments.content: "The ICS supplier has specified that any software installed will result in lack of support."

discussion.content: I'd go with B, mainly since the question really stresses that the team doesn't seem to trust this SCADA, and the other option with VPN simply can't be the answer. That mixed with what everyone else said has me leaning toward B the most.

comments.content: A HIPS would insure the installation of software, since the HIPS itself is software.

discussion.content: A HIPS would prevent the installation of software, hence the need for an HBSS team, so agree with A. Routers set up boundaries between networks. And the staff would be able to use VNC to connect to the engineering workstation to do work. It's definitely A.

D
It's really tough but I still go with D because of the following:
"more efficient use of resources during change windows, better protection of critical infrastructure, and the ability to respond to incidents."
While I'm not sure anything here answers the more efficient part, Network Access Control will better protect critical infrastructure and log monitoring will allow incident response. I'm not sure any other answer really handles the incident "response" part of the question, as HIPS, Firewalls, and WAFs all address incident "prevention"...
Revising this not sure.
I would go with D.
My answer is D. IDS, NAC, and Log monitoring

"The ICS supplier has specified that any software installed will result in lack of support."
I would think this means: no SIEM, and no HIPS. Or could you install the SIEM somewhere else?

Surprised it is A because the scenario clearly states that installing any software would result in them not supporting the environment. A HIPS clearly is something you install on endpoints and would go against this requirement.

comments.content: I agree with B. SIEMENS to monitor/correlate syslog, vpn will allow them to “respond” to incidents, and a firewall to assist in Protecting. I don’t believe D is correct as they don’t give the team better ability to respond, and ids doesn’t “protect”
From the question: "The ICS supplier has specified that any software installed will result in lack of support." Would you not have install some of SIEM software?

discussion.content: Not happy about any of the options but I would go with B. SIEM should provide us with all the info we are missing. a VPN will allow the OT team to connect to the engineering workstation and the firewall will provide a trust boundary between the two networks along with added protection for the unsupported software.

choices.C: Disconnect the host from the network

discussion.content:
I think the given answer is right.
I think the question is more about what you would do in the moment you see that.. You won't have time to deploy an IPS. So ACL is a fast response and make sense.
This shows a C2 server talking back to a client IMHO. An ACL to block access to that IP range until you figure things out makes perfect sense.

comments.content: Big tech companies, like yahoo and google, allow their routers to be pinged. Certainly they have well architected networks.

ACLs are actually very versatile and extensible as far as routers are concerned. The real problem here is that a host on another subnet can ping a router that's not it's default gateway. As a rule, a well architected network will not permit this. MANY secure networks disable ICMP altogether, which isn't a bad idea unless you desperately need it. Even if you do need it, ICMP packets should not travel between subnets, unless you're running an OOB management network for device management. Most likely the offending host is on a guest network or has gained access to a less secure part of the network and is now attacking a production router. The router should just drop the packet with an ACL entry.

You seem to make a case for both B and E. But, although you are going with option B, E seems to be a better option. B would only stop that one particular host. DoS attackers can easily switch hosts. Or maybe I'm missing something?

discussion.content:
Option B.
DoS Protection: Prevent an attack

An organization can adopt the following policy to protect itself against Denial of Service attacks.

 Attacks such as SYN flooding take advantage of bugs in the operating system. Installing security patches can help reduce the chances of such attacks.
 Intrusion detection systems can also be used to identify and even stop illegal activities
 Firewalls can be used to stop simple DoS attacks by blocking all traffic coming from an attacker by identifying his IP.
 Routers can be configured via the Access Control List to limit access to the network and drop suspected illegal traffic.

Isn’t this a kind of ping of death (malformated ICMP request triggering a kind of buffer overflow) performed by 192.168.1.10?
This is a network attack and I would go for “E. Deploy a network-based IPS” (this assumes the IPS is able to detect this attack).
“A” would be only if the constructor is aware of the vulnerability, why not.
“B” would be either isolate the malicious host (do not fix the vuln), either deny all ICMP (removed ICMP feature totally)
“C” would isolate the malicious host (do not fix the vuln on router side)
“D” Network attacks are not file based.

questions.question_text: An information security manager conducted a gap analysis, which revealed a 75% implementation of security controls for high-risk vulnerabilities, 90% for medium vulnerabilities, and 10% for low-risk vulnerabilities. To create a road map to close the identified gaps, the assurance team reviewed the likelihood of exploitation of each vulnerability and the business impact of each associated control. To determine which controls to implement, which of the following is the MOST important to consider?

discussion.content:
B
Kind of a terrible question, but here we go:
 A. KPI - Key Performance Indicator, has absolutely nothing to do with likelihood of an exploitation occurring. Not the answer.
 B. KRI - Key Risk Indicator, the likelihood of something happening *IS* a KRI--this is the answer.
 C. GRC - Governance, Risk Management, and Compliance. Sort of tangentially applicable to the question, but definitely not the answer.
 D. BIA - Business Impact Analysis - Definitely not the answer, this has more to do with categorizing the scope of risk IF it happens, not whether or not it is likely to happen.
Verified by ISO 27001 Auditors. Legal Compliance goes before everything even Business Impact so C.

comments.content: This is a separate issue from doing a quantitative assessment of Key Risk Indicators to determine which controls to put into place. Legal Compliance and GRC principals will say things like "protect customer data." That isn't actually useful in this instance. KRI will say "exploit A requires 27 predisposing conditions, but exploit B requires 0 and they have a similar impact on business compliance... so fix exploit B ASAP."

discussion.content:
Maybe: BIA ? Or maybe KRI?
To determine which controls to implement, you need to know what the greatest risks are, and what their impact could be. 
GRC is about "Governance, Risk Management, and Compliance." The question has nothing to do with governance, or compliance. 
Reference:
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/grc.asp

questions.question_text:
A development team is testing an in-house-developed application for bugs. During the test, the application crashes several times due to null pointer exceptions.
Which of the following tools, if integrated into an IDE during coding, would identify these bugs routinely?

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. Static code analyzer? 
I doubt the correct answer is D. Fuzzing utility. 
I don't think fuzzing utilities are commonly built in IDEs. Also, such tools are not commonly used to find null pointer exceptions. 
A static code analyzer is more likely to built into an IDE, and they are commonly used to find null pointer bugs.
Reference:
https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/1108792.1108798

I choose B.
Fuzzing may be a good testing tool with randomized feeds, but Fuzzing is only leading to crash/pass result, but not allocating where the "Null Pointer Exception" is. 
The process/tool of Static Code Analyzing can allocate "Null Pointer Exception".
The answer is B

D
Fuzzing actually specifically finds null pointer crashes, pretty efficiently.
https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2018/08/exploitable-or-not-exploitable-using.html

comments.content: Yes but the questions states integrated into IDE during coding. SCA is only answer here. Fuzzing is done at UAT in SDLC, after code development
Are fuzzing utilities commonly "integrated into an IDE" ?
